reviewText: Check out (...) for more info. My child started watching these fantastic videos at 8 months old, so we could teach her sign language. She is not hearing impaired but we thought it beneficial to teach her sign language as a second language to help her communictae with us before she could talk. She loved the videos and even asked to watch them. She did her first sign at 10 months and asked for 'Milk". Now she is 2 years old an still mesmerized by the videos adn loves watching them. She now knows all the signs from the first three videos and signs them often. She is also talking a lot now and signing has in no way impaired her speech or slowed it down.These videos are pleaseing to the eye both for children adn grown ups. Many children sign the signs adn it is also repeeated verbally to help your hearing child to pick up the words. they are bright colourful adn the songs are beautiful adn very catchy.I would recommend these videos to anyone interested in teaching sign to their children.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would rate this a very high four or a lowish five.First the positive:I like that first the written word is flashed on the screen- Ball (for example). Then you see the item on the screen in a natural setting or as a cartoon. Then you see a mother doing the signing. After that you see kids doing the sign language as you see a wide variety of examples of that item. Big balls, little balls, orange balls and green balls. Then you see more kids doing the sign for the item. And at the end of the segment, the mother doing the sign for ball again.WE were quickly able to pick up several of the signs and begin using them in our daily speaking. With a little bit watching every day, we picked up many signs that were easy to use and encorporate daily.The negative:Very few negatives. One negative was that there was no sign taught for please and thank you. These are easy signs and should have been included in the first video I believe. The other negative for us, and my kids are a bit older and wanted to learn how to put some of those signs together. For example, it taught mother and it taught dog. They would have liked to see someone do mother dog. However, this is a starting video and I can understand why it didn't do that- it was just a negative for my children.Overall, a great video. Very educational and very helpful in learning to sign. Well worth the money.Enjoy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are wondering about a great video for your toddler or child to watch, this is it!Volume 1 is a basic introduction to the words toddlers would most use.  It is very easy to follow.Signing Time is a great way to introduce children to a second language, ASL.  It is also the perfect way for babies to communicate before they develop speech.  I can't count the times we've prevented a temper tantrum!  These videos have really given my daughter confidence because she knows she can use signs to tell us what she wants, even when she does not know the word or cannot yet speak it clearly.  These videos have also given us a great way to communicate with my young cousin who is disabled, and any Deaf people we may meet.  Be sure to check out [...]

reviewText: I bought this because I wanted to make communication easier for my 17th month old daughter and her deaf friend. I can't tell you how amazing it is that she was able to pick up these signs in less than a week! It also has eliminated issues with her communicating basic needs with me. Instead of pointing at something and saying. "aaa, aaaa" I know what she wants. I wish I could afford the whole set of these videos.

reviewText: I bought this video when my daughter was 11 months old. She is now 2 and 1/2 years old. She loves watching the video and hearing the songs. The videos reinforced what I was already teaching her. After a couple of weeks of watching the videos her signing exploded! She was eager to learn new signs that it was hard keeping up with her. The videos are so well constructed that my daughter learned to recognize the words on the screen, meaning she could say the word and do the sign for it even before they did. My goal was for my daughter to be able to communicate with me before she could verbalize her wants and needs. With the help of these videos we achieved that. We couldn't wait for new videos to come out as she had mastered all the signs on the first 3 videos within the first 6 months. Now we are moving on to expanding our ASL and will buy volumes 4-6. I can't say enough great things about vol. 1-3, except for BUY THEM and see for yourself "D
summary: Best ASL video for children and parents alike!

reviewText: We love Signing Time. We always will! Both of my sons have been watching it since they were little. It's extremely educational, keeps them interested, and is entertaining. Rachel is the best!

reviewText: Imagine, communicating clearly and quickly with a toddler who isn't yet able to speak! This series of videos is easy-to-learn, fun for the child, and excellent in clarity and educational approach.The children see the sign performed, hear the word, see the picture of the word and hear the music (often a little song) using the word. The "cousins", Alex and Leah, play along and other kids join in signing too!I am able to communicate with my grandchildren easily and they are able to "speak" with me about what they need and want.They do teach "please" and "thank you". We haven't learned the sign for M&M;'s yet, but I am hoping. The sign for Grampa looks a little bit like a moose, but that's okay.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We discovered Signing Time while researching ASL (American Sign Language) as a 2nd language for our children. We knew we wanted to teach ASL as a 2nd language because of the many benefits such as earlier communication. You can communicate with your baby as young as 8 months old, maybe even younger. What a gift to know what your child needs before they can tell you with spoken words! For more information on the benefits of ASL check out the Signing Time website at [...]We love this volume of Signing Time. The songs are wonderful and work very well in a school setting as well as at home.  The songs are very catchy so you will find they get stuck in your head. Alex and Leah do a great job. We love to see the 2 friends/cousins interacting together.We like that the written word comes on the screen first and then they show the sign. It is very helpful for practicing the signs. It is like a video flashcard. It also helps children develop reading skills because they start to recognize the written word that goes with the sign. We love watching the children do the signs because you see lots of different kids and lots of different skill levels. It gives you an idea of how your child might make the sign at different ages. Rachel also does the sign so you can clearly see the proper way to do it.The song during the credits is a great way to learn additional signs that were not covered in the show. You can really add to your signing vocabulary if you pay attention.I highly recommend this volume of signing time as well as the other 5 in the series. As a mother and a teacher I can say it is truly the best educational tool I have found for teaching ASL to children (and adults too). I hope they make many more and I will buy them all without hesitation. These shows are a labor of love for these families and we are thankful they chose to share with us.
summary: Alex and Leah are the best

reviewText: My 24 year old daughter with Down syndrome loves this series and can communicate better after learning the signs from the show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After my youngest child was born with heart defects and Trisomy 21, the Early Intervention team recommended signing with him to aid in communication. We bought and borrowed various videos to learn to sign with him. Few ever held his (or our) interest. When the first Signing Time video came out, a friend on a Down syndrome board raved about how great it was, and how quickly her daughter learned all the signs in it. That was good enough a recommendation for me, and I ordered it. Within days of receiving it, my son (2 at the time) was signing most of the signs from the video. Signing Time motivated him more than any other signing video had done. He began wanting to know more than just the signs the video taught, and he pushed me to learn more ASL just to keep up with him. We love Signing Time, and have bought every new volume as soon as they are released.I highly recommend them for every child!
Title: N/A

reviewText: My friend recommended this DVD series (along with the music CD) and I bought it, sight unseen...My daughter, 1 1/2 years old, LOVES it! She starts signing from the very beginning intro song and tries so hard!  I love to watch her, it makes me giddy happy to see her bob her head up and down to the beat while moving her hands like on the screen.  Even my older kids (11 and 5 yr old boys) will sit through this DVD over and over and sign.  I must say, they are all getting quite good!!! We are doing this because we have a little cousin who is deaf. Who knew that this series would be so fun AND effective for all ages?! Bravo!  MORE! MORE! (yes, I'm putting my fingertips together in the sign as I say , "MORE!")
summary: My 18 month old is a signing genius now!

reviewText: I'd been considering buying a sign language video for my daughter shortly after she turned 18 months, when I could tell she had more control over her hand movements - after reading the reviews, I purchased this one, and volume 2, right before she turned 20 months. They are both wonderful! The DVD's themselves are very entertaining, and very fun to watch. And they make it fun to learn and try the signs. Within 2 weeks my daughter was doing about 5 signs - and I was floored when she started doing them out in public - she saw an infant, did the sign for 'baby' and at the same time said "baby!", it was amazing! And she loves to sign 'bear', 'please', 'more' and 'thank you'. My relatives are so impressed, and I'm bursting with pride. I know it's helping her vocabulary too, at 21 months, she can now say almost every word that they sign in these videos. I'm ready to get the next volumes, I know they'll be just as good!

reviewText: This is a well-produced video that is a moderately entertaining introducton to ASL for kids, but which is disappointingly thin on content and not of a great deal of use for learning sign for either kids or parents wishing to teach their babies some sign.Signing is introduced one word at a time, with only a dozen or so words making it into the brief 30 minutes. Those signs that are shown are covered well, with multiple toddlers, the adult guide, and sometimes cartoon characters making the signs, all to a mixture of backdrops of live-action and animation. For instance, 'cat' shows a cartoon cat, real cats, and the adult and several kids making the sign interspersed.But there's just not enough material here to be useful. The video neither explains in depth how to go about learning to sign, nor does it address specific audiences -- for instance, baby-sign learners (all the kids using signs are older), those seeking to learn full ASL as a second language, or parents.As such, it has some entertainment value, but is not that useful. I hate  to give a nicely-done video a low rating, but there's no real educational design here or way to make it fit into learning sign except as supplemental material -- and even then, it's just not got a lot of depth.The DVD has basic chapter features, but the "extras" are misleading. The "song" the packaging promised, for instance, is just over the closing credits, not an extra sing-along while signing -- and it's far too sophisticated for beginners.For baby-sign learners, I'd recommend instead the Joseph Garcia book and video as an introduction -- and a decent basic reference -- the video is only in VHS but has about five times as many words as this DVD, and the accompanying book has decent illustrations, all for a price comparable to this DVD. For learning ASL, any kid old enough to read or adult can use one of the ASL-as-second-language textbooks designed to teach it as a natural language.
summary: Well-Produced, but Very Thin on Depth of Content

reviewText: I bought these about 3 months about for our little girl who was 16 months at the time.  We have the first 6 dvd's in the series and have made it through the first 5 and they are wonderful dvd's.  They show Rachel signing and then children doing the sign all the while saying the word they are signing and showing Rachel doing it again and again.  The songs are great as well.  Our little girl can do about 40 different signs and we watch them as a family and learn the signs together.  She had no developmental delays, I just wanted to be able to communicate better with her.  She is already potty trained and has used the "potty" sign from day one.  She does not talk too much and this series had been wonderful!! I do not understand why this series was given a 1 star by some people, this is not a movie star production and does not have the budget a Disney einstein show does, this is a loving mother who has a deaf child and wanted to help other like her and she DID IT!!!  I would give these 10 stars if I could.  I am recommending them to anyone who will listen now, our little girl loves them and does not watch anything else on tv and she asks for it by name.....signing it!

reviewText: This DVD - and the entire Signing Time series are wonderfully simple introductions to sign language.  Even though the series was intended for very young children, Signing Time also provides a positive and non-threatening introduction to sign language for grandparents and others who want to learn how to communicate with a deaf child.
summary: Five Stars - A Simple And Comfortable Introduction to Basic Sign Language

reviewText: I am a young adult who has used "Signing Time" as a springboard in an attempt to get back into practice with sign language. It has proved invaluable to me! Rachel, Alex, and Leah make it easy and fun to remember the signs with catchy music and plenty of child and adult models for each sign. Signing Time! is a useful and fun tool allowing kids and adults to learn this beautiful, visual language.

reviewText: Each of the videos is better than the last.  I was lucky to have bought all three at the same time (or I may not have invested in the other two).While some signing videos are boring to kids *after they learn the signs*, thanks to the cute songs, these three are set up in such a way kids will continue to be interested long after the other videos turn into library donations.Whether you are trying to teach your baby that words mean things or just getting something entertaining for your four year old, this is a great set of videos.It also has CC.
summary: Interesting after children learn the signs
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video is an absolute MUST BUY if you're teaching your kids sign language. My 2 1/2 yr old now signs "Milk" "Dog" "Ball" & "More" and he understands about 10 (if I tell him go get me the [sign ball] then he says "BALL!" and gets the ball).This video is absolutely amazing and it's really cute. I'll admit, I love watching it with him. I show him how to do each sign then I do it myself. He LOVES the "Songs" portion of the DVD and makes me play them a few times a piece wich I don't mind because the songs are cute (especially "Show me a sign"). His favorite part of the DVD is when they sign the word "More" and tons of CGI balls fill the playhouse, he cracks up everytime he sees it (they do it for "more" and "want").The DVD has some cartooning but is mostly actual kids. We have the other 2 as well along with the CD (wich we haven't listened to yet).I HIGHLY recommend this DVD along with "Talking Hands" and "Treasure Chest Toys and Signs" (only availible on VHS) for toddlers. "Baby Signs 1&2" are also good DVDs but they have ALOT of signs on them (75 on the first DVD and 100 on the second) so I watch those and use the signs on the DVD to "talk" to my son.
summary: We've only had this DVD for 2wks and my 2yr signs!!!!!!!!!!!
